Seneca Valley JROTC cadets hosted a 9/11 commemorative event this morning outside of the senior high school.

On Patriot Day, we honor the memories of the lives lost on September 11, 2001, and of every hero who gave their life since that day to protect our safety and freedom. We come together united. Our values endure and the memory of our loved ones never fades.

As a community and a nation, we honor the lives of the victims of 9/11. We commend the heroic and courageous actions of the first responders, rescue workers and volunteers.

For the innocent men, women and children who lost their lives on an airplane, at the World Trade Center, at the Pentagon, in Somerset County and on the streets of New York.

For civil servants, firefighters, police officers, and military personnel who dedicated and lost their lives protecting our safety, our freedom and democracy.

We will never forget.

To watch a live video of this event, visit our Facebook profile page or go to this link: https://www.facebook.com/SenecaValleySD/videos/239461314106397.
#NeverForget #Honor911

An impactful lesson from last school year has carried over, possibly for a lifetime, for two Seneca Valley freshmen.
Last fall, Lihini Ranaweera and Friyana Sepai, in partnership with Classrooms Without Borders (CWB) of Pittsburgh, participated in a Holocaust Immersion Day where they sang a Yiddish song for their classmates. CWB reached out to these two talented students again, this time for their Open Minds, Open Hearts Fundraiser.
The virtual event will be held at 6:30 p.m. on Thursday, Sept. 10 featuring the musical talents of Miss Ranaweera and Miss Sepai.
The young ladies will speak live about their experiences with CWB and learning about the Holocaust. Afterward, a recording of their song will be shared.
The hope is to help others across the nation and abroad learn about the incredible impact CWB has had on schools like Seneca Valley.
To attend, visit https://classroomswithoutborders.org/fundraiser/ and RSVP.

#SVProud #SVStandOut #SVRaiderPride #SV2021 Classrooms Without Borders Pittsburgh PA

Ryan Gloyer Middle School (RGMS) partnered up with Concordia for a purpose!

Science classrooms at RGMS recently gathered all of their protective glasses and donated more than 300 pairs to Concordia at Villa St. Joseph’s nursing home and rehabilitation center in Baden, PA. Allyson Spencer, a parent in the District who works at the facility, saw a need and knew RGMS would be the first to step up and help. The protective glasses will help keep Concordia’s caregivers, nurses, staff members and residents safe.

“Please accept our most sincere thanks for your generous donation of goggles to our facility during this unprecedented time in our nation and our world,” stated Rachelle Arnold, skilled nursing administrator. “Please know that it makes a huge difference in protecting a very vulnerable geriatric population and the healthcare workers who take care of those patients.”

Seneca Valley’s 8th Annual Seneca Valley Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) Fair was held yesterday, in the Seneca Valley Senior High School Gymnasium.
At the event, there were 117 student participants with 70 projects on display. Several projects, through the use of the SV Genetics Lab, focused on Biofilms as well as environmental DNA found in the creek.
The Seneca Valley Foundation (SVF) is proud to say their fundraising efforts have provided STEM mini-grants that assisted a number of students with high-intensity projects as part of the annual STEM Fair. This year, SVF supported a project that researched manganese, a mineral element, and which metals “make the cut.”
Over 35 community experts volunteered to judge projects, where they discussed methods, results and conclusions with students. These experts offered written and verbal feedback, as well as advice on how to deepen and enrich students’ projects.

#STEMatSV #SV1920 #SVProud
